Six monstrous eighteen-wheel diesels, coming at u their smokestacks blasting. Sound grows louder, as we beg to hear snatches of Citizens Band Radio talk over:

Voices fade and titles and credits begin. "Black Smoke Bl Over Eighteen Wheels" by Red Simpson comes up in the b.g. the six trucks blast right over camera.
of the trucks driving through an entrance gate to a huge  parking lot. Over the gate is a sign reading: "GEORGIA TR ROADEO STATE FINALS." Music and credits continue.

Macks, Kenworths, Whites and Jimmys, all polished to a  mirrored finish. Truck drivers decked out in their flashi western outfits. The stands filled with spectators on the edge of their seats, watching the gearjammers put their r through tests of skill and reflexes -- parallel parking,  driving around eggs, through complicated barricades, etc.

a customized white Cadillac convertible pulling into the  Roadeo grounds. The Caddy has mounted chrome quarter hors on each front fender, bull horns on the front bumper, sta rifles displayed in the rear. Garish. The car's Texas lic plate reads "Mr. Big."

The Cadillac stops. Two men climb out and wend their way  through the trucks and spectators. Camera tracks behind t Although we can't see their faces, we see that one man is pudgy and decked out in a fancy white western suit and ha The other is younger, tall, skinny and wearing a grey wes suit and hat. Kyle Brand and his son Dickey.
The crowd roars, as the trucks race through an obstacle  course.
Camera still on their backs.
(referring to race) Is that Bandit in the lead?
If that sumbitch was in the race,  he'd be in the winner's circle by  now.
I still think this whole idea is  dumb, pop.
Then it must be a helluva idea.
Kyle laughs. His laugh then turns into a hacking cough.
Why don't we just rent a Lear jet  and haul it back ourselves?
Because I wanna see this hot shot  Bandit do something that can't be  done. Besides, there's nothing I  like better than breaking legends.
He laughs, coughs again, continues walking.
(not getting it) But if it can't be done, how's he  gonna do it?
That's the point, Dickey.
Oh.
Now, you just find him, son.
Yes, sir.
Dickey crosses to a trucker couple, polishing up their ch rig.
Say, hoss. Where might I locate the  Bandit?
Ain't seen him.
(immediately) Over there behind his rig.
The Husband shoots his old lady a jealous look. Dickey re Kyle and they head toward Bandit LaRue's truck.

as they come to the only battered, beaten-up eighteen-whe at the entire Truck Roadeo. It looks like it hasn't been  washed since it left the showroom. On one side of the truck is a faded and peeling mural of stagecoach being held up. A teamster and a shotgun guard  have their hands high in the air and a Bandit on horsebac has a six-gun pointed at them. An elaborate CB radio antenna grows out of the cab beside the driver's door.
as they round the truck and stop in their tracks.

A hammock is stretched from the cab of the truck to an oa tree. A man wearing a faded denim western shirt, open wit the sleeves rolled up, levis and silver-toed cowboy boots lying in the hammock. A cowboy hat covers his face.
as shadows fall across the figure. The man slowly tips ba his hat and we see he's in his thirties, boyishly handsom with a cocky smile. Bandit LaRue.

And for the first time we get a look at Kyle and Dickey.  Kyle is wearing sunglasses and diamond rings on every fin His smile is as tasteless as the suit he wears. Dickey is in his early twenties. Blonde, blue-eyed and sc to death of his old man. Bandit looks at them for a moment, then casually pulls th hat back over his face.
Aw, ain't you glad to see me, Bandit?
(hat over his face) Yeah, it's the highlight of my day.
There's a long pause interrupted by Kyle's hacking cough.
(to Dickey) What's he get if he wins here?
(hat over his face) If...?
Five thou.
Chickenshit money.
Kyle coughs again.
(hat over his face) Could you turn your head?
Bandit gets up and begins untying the hammock from the tr Kyle crosses to him.
Look, Kyle; I ain't in this Truck  Roadeo for the money. It's the  challenge. You know, the ecstasy of  victory, the agony of defeat.
Kyle looks out at the cheering crowd.
I can't believe there's two thousand  people here to watch a bunch of guys  back up their trucks.
America's bored. (then) Now, what do you want?
You to forget this dumbass Roadeo  and take on a real challenge.
As Bandit turns to him, we:
Bandit, wearing aviator shades and his cowboy hat, is bac the truck up and shouting down to Kyle and Dickey on the  ground.
You're crazy, man. Smart dresser,  but crazy.
What's the matter? Legend has it  Bandit LaRue's king of the road.
I can make it to Texarkana and back  in twenty-eight hours... that's no  sweat.
It ain't ever been done before, hot  shit.
(smiles at Dickey,  then) See, running Coors Beer east of Texas  is what bothers me. It makes me a  bootlegger.
I hear a few weeks ago you smuggled  sixteen Beaners up to West Virginia.
You know how rumors start.
I think you're just yellow.
Wonderful psychology. Why don't you  say something about my mom? (then) Excuse me.
Bandit drives toward the starting line for another event. Kyle and Dickey run alongside.
(coughs, then) Look, you make this little run for  me, I'll buy you a new rig.
(indicating truck) Last year, this was a new rig.
But it wasn't a Kenworth.
Dickey turns to his father, stunned, as Bandit stops the  truck.
(sotto) Pop, a K-Whopper's worth seventy  thou.
(correcting) Seventy-two five. (then) Why do you want this barley pop so  bad?
He's thirsty.
Bandit smiles at Dickey again.
I got a boy running in the Peach  Tree Classic tomorrow and when he  wins, I wanna celebrate in style.
How much style?
Four hundred cases worth. (a long pause) Well?
(a beat) You paying for the gas?
Kyle smiles that unwinning smile and takes out a huge wad bills, as we:
Picturesque. Bandit's eighteen-wheeler rolling down the  Georgia highway, past lush green meadows and endless acre of pines. Over this:
Whaddya mean, we're not going to the  show tonight?

And for the first time, we get a real look inside the rig It's quite a set-up. The opposite of the outside. Home on the road. Sheepskin over the two front seats, a poster of Raquel We in a bikini tacked above the windshield, under which is a bumper sticker reading: "Do It For Truckers." On the dash board, a St. Christopher medal and a chattering skull. Al a stereo tape deck and the best Citizens Band Radio outfi money can buy. Bandit is on the C.B.
(into mike) Hot Pants, I got no choice. I gotta  make a run to Texarkana. Over.
(over CB) But you been promising to take me  for three weeks.
(into mike) Baby, I...
(over CB) Break. Break.
(over CB) Yeah, breaker; come on.
(over CB) Hot Pants, this here is Sugar Man.  I'll take you to the show tonight.  Pick you up at seven. How am I hitting  you?
(over CB) Bull's-eye, Sugar Man. Bandit?

(over CB) Go sit on a cold carrot.
Bandit looks at the mike and we:
Bandit's truck pulls to a stop in front of a small white  clapboard house.

Most of the furniture is old and what isn't, is covered w plastic. No fancy carpets or objects d'art. On the coffee table is an open, colorfully illustrated Bible. A blonde  wood television set sits in a corner of the room. There a a lot of toy trucks lying around and over the mantel is a oil painting of a fancy eighteen-wheeler with an epitaph  under it reading: "I'd rather be a truck driver, than be millionaire..." Bandit is trying to get into the bedroom, but his path is being blocked by a faded Georgia beauty lost somewhere in her thirties. Waynette Snow.
(trying to get past  her) Goddamn, Waynette; you sure do look  foxy today. If you weren't already  married, I'd...
Don't give me that horseshit, Bandit.  You ain't seeing him.
(determined) Yes, I am.
(equally determined) No, you ain't.
A scrawny little Kid runs through the room, followed by a even scrawnier mutt.
Hi, Uncle Bandit.
(turning to Kid) He ain't your damn uncle and get  that mutt outta here. He just peed  all over my hot curlers!
Bandit takes the moment to slide past Waynette and duck i the bedroom.

is dark. The venetian blinds are drawn. Bandit hurries in the room with Waynette still hollering in the b.g. He passes a French Provincial dresser with a small fleet model trucks on top and crosses to a Lump sleeping face d on a double bed.
(shaking the Lump) Cledus.
(not moving) No.
(shaking him again) Wake up, man; I just got us a hot  run for big bucks.
Bandit goes to the closet and begins tossing clothes onto the bed.
(slowly rolling over) Whadda we have to do -- kidnap the  Pope?
(from closet) How'd you know?
He comes out of the closet with the rest of the clothes a tosses them on the bed, then crosses to the dresser drawe and throws a pair of socks and underwear at Cledus.
Look, all we gotta do is make a run  to Texarkana... (under his breath) ...in twenty-eight hours.

Cledus Snow slowly comes up from under the covers and we our first glimpse of him. He's thirty-three, but you'd ne take him for a day under forty. Trucker all the way. He's wearing boxer shorts and an undershirt. As he reaches acr to the nightstand and puts on a pair of glasses:
Twenty-eight hours! You're outta  your gord.
Is that any way to talk to your ole  partner? (pulling back blanket) Look, it's only nine hundred miles  each way.
(figuring quick) That means we gotta average ninety- four miles per. (lying back down) Forget it.
No one's ever done it before. This'll  put us on the map.
Or in the slammer.
Did I tell you they're gonna give us  a brand new Kenworth?
(sitting up) Waynette!

Bandit sits inside the cab of the truck, nervously tappin his foot and watching Cledus' kids play football on the f lawn. The mutt keeps getting in their way. Bandit hits the horn and an instant later, Cledus steps o the front porch, followed by Waynette. He's wearing a pla shirt, levis, a large engraved cowboy belt and a thermal  vest.
(handing him a thermos) This ain't fair. You're letting him  talk you into this.
(buttoning shirt) I swear to God, pumpkin; I'll be  back before you know it. (sly smile) And then I'll make you glad you was  born a woman.
Well, I just might not be waiting  this time.
Bandit toots again. Waynette gives him "the finger."
Honey, please... Don't be this way.  You know I'd do anything for you.
Anything?
Cledus nods.
Take Fred.
The eighteen-wheeler heading west, stacks open. Over:
Believe me, man; Fred'll be no  problem.
Yeah, I can tell he's gonna be a  major asset.
Fred, the mutt, lays with his head slumped over Bandit's  leg. Cledus is at the wheel, wearing clip-on sunglasses.
All right, Fred; enough fun.
Bandit picks Fred up and dumps him onto the sleeper  compartment behind the seats. Then, starts going over a r map.
You know of course, we ain't ever  gonna make it.
(not looking up) Quit being so negative, guy; 'course  we're gonna make it. We ain't never  not made it, have we?
No.
See.
Our asses gonna be in a sling if we  get caught.
(looking up, straight  to him) And if we don't, they're gonna be  riding high in a brand new Kenworth.
As "Truck Driving Man" by Red Steagall starts over, Cledu looks at Bandit, sighs -- then punches it.
roaring down the highway. Music continues, as slowly day  becomes night and the truck whizzes across the Alabama an Mississippi State Lines.
The rig is parked on the shoulder under a highway light.  Bandit and Cledus stand by the side of the truck, as Fred wanders aimlessly around the grassy knoll off the shoulde
(snapping his fingers  impatiently) How long's this gonna take?
I don't know, man. Ask him?
(nervously) We gotta let the slack out, Cledus;  this is costing us time.
If you ask me, I think we should  make that run to Choo Choo Town and  pick up that load of lumber. Nice.  Easy. And within the law.
Also boring.
But I still don't think...
Bandit walks away from Cledus in mid-sentence, heading fo the rear of the truck.
What are you doin' now?
(starting to open  rear doors) Running blocker.

as Bandit guides the Cobra down the ramp. Cledus quickly  folds up the ramp and dumps it back into the truck. He sl the metal doors closed and crosses to the Cobra.

(into mike; after a  beat) Bandit?

Bandit I and II screaming through the Mississippi night.  Over this a driving Doug Kershaw fiddle.

as he eases up on the pedal and fires up his CB mike.

As night slowly begins fading back into day, Bandit I and Bandit II blast across the Arkansas State Line.
behind a sign that reads: Welcome to Texarkana, Texas. A  beat and two blurs whip past camera. Bandit I and II.

Shit! No one's here.
(checking watch) That's 'cause we're damn near an  hour ahead of schedule.
Let's keep it that way.

(whistles low) Liquid gold.
(nods) Redneck heaven.
They cross back to the large sliding door and as Bandit p it open, Cledus jumps into the truck's cab and begins bac the big rig up to the loading dock.

You know how to drive one of these  things?
Can a pig whistle?

Bandit climbs into the seat of the fork-lift and turns th key. The engine roars to life. He grins and confidently t it into gear. The fork-lift leaps backward and begins spe wildly around the warehouse.
(yelling) Hit the brakes!

as it smashes into stacks of Coors cases, sending them fl in every direction and tossing Bandit out of the seat -- into the air.
as Bandit crashes to the ground, surrounded by cases of b He looks up to Cledus.

Let's get the hell outta here.
Shouldn't we pay 'em for the damages?

(over CB) We still on schedule?

as Bandit eases off the accelerator and starts to move ar the Girl. But the Girl moves with him, waving and blocking his path Bandit's forced to pull off the road and stop. The Girl r up to the Cobra and opens the door.
(climbing in) Thanks.
(it was nothing) Hey...
The Girl slams the door and turns to Bandit. She's tall a sophisticated. A hyper New Yorker in her late twenties. K McCONNELL.

as Bandit I pulls away in a cloud of dust and squealing t a beat-up VAN passes, going the other way. THREE SHITKICKER KIDS are riding in the Van. They watch B leaving the abandoned "Just Married" car and brake to tur around. Bandit and Kate don't notice.
picking up speed.

Okay. I was in Texas dancing in an  industrial show for Sunkist Oranges.  They say I'm the new Anita Bryant.  But I'm really a dancer from New  York. A lot of credits. Moderate  talent. (rolling on) Anyway, after opening night, I was  walking back to the motor lodge and  suddenly there he was. A tall Texan  with a twenty-nine inch waist. Pure  dynamite.

Look, I'm a twenty-eight year old  hoofer who spends most of her time  with fags. Besides, I'm impulsive.  It runs in the family. We're all  crazy. Mind if I smoke? I can't marry Jerry  Jeff. I mean, we're eventually gonna  have to talk. So, halfway down the  aisle, I turned and split. You think  I'm nuts, right?

Bandit I, do you copy?

Kate McConnell.

Never fails. Bandit gets a chick. I  get...

as a pair of plyers rip it off the side of a car and we E BACK to see:

still parked along the Arkansas Highway -- now almost  completely stripped by the THREE KIDS in the Van. The car up on jacks, as one of the Kids, rolls the last of the fo tires to the rear of the Van. Another kid dumps the chrom stripping into the cab, while the third, unscrews the rad

Hey!

(pleading) I swear to God, officer; the car  was. already like this, we were just  trying to...

Bandit watching the road. Kate watching Bandit.

Why? You have a bowling date?

For a new Kenworth. That's a truck.
(incredulous) A truck? You're doing this for a  truck? That's insanity.

Hey, you could get killed crossing  the street.
An existentialist.
(turns to her) A what?

Bandit and Kate.

Well?...

Having fun.

Driving?
